repnme.cdata!: World Bank projects in private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
Ukraine's European course, declared
            by the supreme state power and supported by society,
            determines the nature of market reforms carried out by the
            Ukrainian Government. This line of reforms is actively
            supported by the World Bank, with its most important
            projects aimed at building up the private sector in Ukraine.
            In 1996 and 1998, the enterprise development adjustment
            loans (EDAL) I and II were implemented in two stages. In
            2002, the World Bank approved granting a loan to Ukraine for
            the private sector development project. This project is a
            systemic (adjustment) type, being oriented not only to the
            extensive development of private enterprises, but also to
            increasing the efficiency and profitability of production,
            and the manufacture of competitive products. The project
            objective is also to ensure that privatized enterprises
            themselves, after acquiring know-how and work experience
            under the conditions of new economic realities, become
            experts and leaders of enterprise restructuring, supporters,
            and implementers of market ideas in the regions.
            Introduction of the latest models of information and
            communication technologies (ICT) can considerably increase
            the efficiency and expeditiousness of decisions approval,
            stimulate the development of the private sector, and
            strengthen civil society in Ukraine. In order to attain
            these goals, a credit agreement on financing the project
            Ukraine: e-development was signed in 2003 between the World
            Bank and the Ukrainian Government. The activities envisaged
            by the project have positive prospects for consolidating
            administrative reform.

repnme.cdata!:
Ukraine - Second Enterprise Development
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            but, although sustainability is being rated
            "likely", questions remain on the practical
            aspects for private sector development, in the absence of
            reforms in various sectors of the economy, such as
            administrative, pension, and energy sector reforms. Among
            the lessons learned, it is conveyed that, given the
            difficult political climate in Ukraine, and the contentious
            relationship between Government and Parliament, it would be
            useful to involve participants, from a variety of political
            spheres, to provide support, and thus create a broad based
            environment to take into account the stakeholders'
            views. In turn, the variety of governmental agencies
            involved in this operation, precluded a strong ownership to
            be accountable for results, therefore, enabling leadership
            on the side of the counterpart, could have been beneficial
            to minimize the many changes occurring in a difficult
            political environment. The usefulness of adjustment
            operations is questioned, in light of the complex
            governmental situation in the country, particularly, as
            economic reform is largely opposed. Nonetheless,
            conditionalities were fulfilled by the issuance of decrees,
            but with a weak subsequent implementation, and, the real
            long-term impact of the project will only be seen, after
            support from technical assistance, and investment operations
            is measurable.

5083435.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Ukraine - Second Enterprise Development
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Enterprise Development
            Adjustment Loan (EDAL) seeks to continue support for the
            Government's privatization and capital markets
            development programs under the first EDAL and the more
            recently initiated accounting, bankruptcy reform and
            deregulation programs. The loan consisting of three equal
            tranches, is expected to disburse quickly upon the
            satisfactory implementation of the agreed adjustment
            measures in the areas of privatization, capital markets,
            accounting reform, bankruptcy reform, and deregulation.
            Privatization reform will demonopolize infrastructure, and
            other enterprises. Capital market developments include
            consolidating regulatory functions of a State Securities and
            Stock Market Commission (SSMC), promoting self-regulatory
            organization, improving regulation, and reforming tax
            system. Accounting reform will establish an institutional
            framework for adopting International Accounting Standards,
            and improve audit standards. Bankruptcy reform will
            introduce a new bankruptcy law. Deregulation will adopt a
            deregulation strategy developed by deregulation experts,
            simplify requirements for business registration, and take
            actions to resolve licensing problems.
